docs.lead_paragraph: The seven common diseases are bipolar disorder, coronary artery disease, Crohn’s disease, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes.

headline.main: Researchers Detect Variations in DNA That Underlie Seven Common Diseases
headline.print_headline: Researchers Detect Variations in DNA That Underlie Seven Common Diseases

docs.snippet: The seven common diseases are bipolar disorder, coronary artery disease, Crohn’s disease, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 Rights Groups Seek End Of Secret U.S. Detentions Six human rights groups released a list of 39 people they believe have been secretly imprisoned by the United States and whose whereabouts are unknown, calling on the Bush administration to abandon such detentions. A18 'Deranged' Man Leaps at Pope A man the Vatican described as ''clearly deranged'' sprang over a barricade and landed a yard or so behind Pope Benedict XVI as he rode in an uncovered popemobile through crowds at St. Peter's Square. A8 Opponents Arrested in Pakistan The Pakistani police have arrested more than 300 political party workers over the past few days in a crackdown before a protest planned against new government curbs on the news media, a government official acknowledged. A19 Palestinians Delay Israel Talks A meeting scheduled between the prime minister of Israel and the Palestinian president has been postponed over what appeared to be the issue of the conditions under which Israel would turn over tax revenues it collects for the Palestinians. A12 Tense Start to G-8 Meeting As the annual Group of 8 meeting began in Germany, the White House said it would hold firm against concrete targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. A14 Deal for Darfur Peacekeeping The United Nations and the African Union struck a tentative deal to end disagreement over the command of a 23,000-soldier joint peacekeeping force proposed for Darfur. A3 NATIONAL A20-32 Technique Raises Hope Of Easing Stem Cell Debate Researchers have come closer to a major goal of regenerative medicine, the conversion of a patient's cells into specialized tissues that might replace those lost to disease. A1 Warning on Diabetes Drugs The Food and Drug Administration has called for the toughest safety warning on two diabetes drugs whose health risks have become a focus of Congressional concern. A1 Candidates to Skip Straw Poll Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain announced that they would skip participation in a key early test of candidate strength, the straw poll in Ames, Iowa. A26 DNA Links Found in 7 Diseases Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them. A32 Immigration Plan Survives The Senate signaled support for major provisions of a comprehensive immigration bill by rejecting many proposed amendments. A31 EDUCATION Inquiry on Loan Company Grows Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, whose scrutiny of student loans has exposed ties between universities and lenders, said that he was broadening his investigation to examine the criteria lenders use when making loans, and whether they violate civil rights statutes. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 9-Year-Old Makes Career Out of Video Games Victor M. De Leon III, a 9-year-old Long Island boy better known as Lil' Poison, is thought to be the world's youngest professional gamer. Victor will appear this weekend at a Major League Gaming event at the Meadowlands. A1 Missing Teenager Found A 15-year-old Connecticut girl who had been missing for nearly a year was found in the house of a business acquaintance of the girl's stepfather, the police said. B1 Project Lawsuit Dismissed A federal judge dismissed the most significant lawsuit against the Atlantic Yards development project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents. B3 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 China Reviews Food Rules Responding to concerns about tainted food and counterfeit drugs, China said that it was overhauling its food and drug safety regulations and would introduce nationwide inspections. A1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES A33 Jim Clark The former sheriff in Selma, Ala., whose violent, highly public attempts to maintain the status quo there in the Jim Crow era are widely believed to have contributed to the success of the voting-rights movement, he was 84. A33 EDITORIAL A34-35 Editorials: Looking for leadership; out from the ethical deep freeze; the inadequacy of civil unions; Lawrence Downes on ''silent amnesty'' and immigration. Columns: Timothy Egan and Nicholas D. Kristof. Bridge E8 Crossword E2 TV Listings E11 Weather B7

docs.lead_paragraph: Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them. The variations pinpoint biological pathways underlying each of the diseases, and researchers hope that as the pathways are analyzed, new drugs and treatments will emerge.

headline.main: Researchers Detect Variations in DNA That Underlie Seven Common Diseases

docs.abstract: British researchers, applying new genomic technique to large group of patients, detect DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them; variations pinpoint underlying biological pathways; researchers hope that as pathways are analyzed, new drugs and treatments will emerge (M)
docs.snippet: Applying a new genomic technique to a large group of patients, researchers in Britain have detected DNA variations that underlie seven common diseases, discovering unexpected links between them.      The variations pinpoint biological pathways...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last night's debate among the Republican candidates for the G.O.P. presidential nomination gave the top contenders ample time to explain some of their core beliefs. Among the more memorable moments were Senator John McCain's ardent defense of his belief in the current Iraq war strategy and impassioned defense of his support for the immigration legislation; former Mayor Rudy Giuliani's succinct responses to questions about the Iraq invasion, terrorism and his humorous comeback to the sound glitches caused by lightning from a storm; and former Gov. Mitt Romney's elaborative explanation and embrace of his Mormon faith.
docs.abstract: Responses on a few issues -- outside of Iraq and immigration -- were quite striking.
docs.snippet: Responses on a few issues -- outside of Iraq and immigration -- were quite striking.

headline.main: The Doctor’s Computer Will See You Now (5 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Republican presidential candidates debate hosted by CNN, WMUR-TV and The New Hampshire Union Leader. The participants were Senator Sam Brownback, the former Virginia Gov. James Gilmore, the former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani, Rep. Duncan Hunter, the former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, Sen. John McCain, Rep. Ron Paul, the former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney, Rep. Tom Tancredo, and the former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson and the moderator was Wolf Blitzer.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Physician, Upgrade Thyself,'' by Thomas Goetz (Op-Ed, May 30): Having electronic medical records is a great idea and would be a step toward simplifying life for all, including the patients.

headline.main: The Doctor's Computer Will See You Now

docs.abstract: Five letters comment on May 30 Thomas Goetz Op-Ed article lauding WorldVistA software for medical records; Ursula Wertheim agrees that having information readily available to all of her doctors would be advantageous; Dr John R Bruner says better idea than centralized records is to have portable records on memory stick; Dr Mitchell Kahn warns that software is not user-friendly; Jay L Finkelstein argues that computer illiteracy among doctors could lead to problems with privacy; Catherine Coveney urges patients to keep their own records; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Physician, Upgrade Thyself,'' by Thomas Goetz (Op-Ed, May 30):     Having electronic medical records is a great idea and would be a step toward simplifying life for all, including the patients.
